channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Declaring ‘Crisis,’ South Korean Firms Tell Managers to Work 6 Days a Week
item.description: The move by some influential companies has raised concerns about work-life balance in a country where long hours at the office are common.

item.title: How Norway Became a Powerhouse for All Seasons
item.description: With money from an oil boom, Norway, a force at the Winter Olympics for generations, is now churning out elite performers in track, soccer and other sports, too.

item.title: Why has the world’s happiest country just plummeted in expat rankings?
item.description: Finland has been voted one of the worst places to live as an expat in 2024.

item.title: Japan Needs Foreign Workers. It’s Just Not Sure It Wants Them to Stay.
item.description: Foreign employees have become much more visible in Japan. But policies designed only for short-term stays may hurt the country in the global competition for labor.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s search for a running mate.

item.title: The untold story of how Exxon scored a $1 trillion oil bonanza that 30 rivals passed up
item.description: “When everyone else was pulling back, we were leaning in,” says Liam Mallon, president of Exxon’s production division.

item.title: Hurricane Debby Rapidly Gaining Strength as It Heads to Florida
item.description: It is expected to hit Florida early Monday, before moving over Georgia and South Carolina, bringing potentially catastrophic flooding.

item.title: At Least 70 Dead as Bangladesh Protests Grow; Curfew Is Reinstated
item.description: Expanded student protests this weekend, after more than 200 people were killed in a government crackdown in July, have plunged the country into a particularly dangerous phase.

item.title: Goldman Sachs raises U.S. recession odds to 25% from 15%
item.description: “We continue to see recession risk as limited,” the Goldman economists led by Jan Hatzius said in a report to clients on Sunday.

item.title: Harris Faces Party Divisions as She Chooses a Running Mate
item.description: The vice president conducted interviews with potential candidates over the weekend and has fielded concerns from donors and activists over the choice.

item.title: Japan Needs Foreign Workers. It’s Just Not Sure It Wants Them to Stay.
item.description: Foreign employees have become much more visible in Japan. But policies designed only for short-term stays may hurt the country in the global competition for labor.

item.title: Supreme Court justice blasts the increase in laws and regulations, defends Trump immunity ruling
item.description: “Here we have, for the first time in our history, one presidential administration bringing criminal charges against a prior president. It’s a grave question, right? Grave implications.”

item.title: How the 9/11 Plea Deal Came Undone
item.description: A case that had mostly drifted from public consciousness in 12 years of proceedings is back in the spotlight and no closer to trial.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: For Israelis, Jittery Wait for Retaliatory Strikes Stretches Into a New Week
item.description: Airlines have suspended service to Israel ahead of expected attacks by Iran and its proxy in Lebanon, Hezbollah. That has left tens of thousands of Israelis unable to return home, an Israeli official said.

item.title: Why did Warren Buffett dump Apple stock? He could be managing risk or raising cash to snap up bargains in a recession
item.description: Since 2016, when Warren Buffett first bought Apple, shares have soared almost 900%, delivering Berkshire billions of dollars worth of unrealized profits.
